msContents.summary: A nearly-complete copy of the Dīvān by Ḥasan Sijzī Dihlavī (ca. 1253–1338), a significant medieval Sufi poet of India. An early proponent of the Persian ghazal, or 'lyrical poem', his style tremendously influenced later Persian poets such as Ḥafiẓ Shīrāzī (1315–1390). A close friend of another famous early Indian poet and fellow devotee of the Chīshtīyyah Sufi Order, Amīr Khusraw Dihlavī (1253–1325), both men followed Niẓām al-Dīn Awliyā (1238–1325). beside whom they are buried in the Niẓām al-Dīn Dargāh shrine complex in Delhi. Munʻim al-Dīn al-Awḥadī, scion of a prominent family of artists in Shiraz, Iran, completed this richly illuminated manuscript in Jumādà I, year 913 AH (Sept.–Oct. 1507 CE), soon after the establishment of the Safavid dynasty.

msItem.explicit: برگ ۲۷۰ر (folio 270a): لطف خذا که بر همهٔ واجب سلام تست * گو حثم کن یکی بیکی عین نام تست
msItem.colophon: برگ ۲۷۰ر (folio 270a): تمّ الدیوان بعون الله الملک المنان علی اقلام تراب اقدام کلاب احباب ابی تراب منعم‌الدین الاوحدی غفر ذنوبه و ستر عیوبه فی جمادی الاولی سنه ثلث عشر وتسعمآئه
Completed by Munʻim al-Dīn al-Awḥadī in the month of Jumādà I, year 913 AH (Sept.–Oct. 1507 CE).

supportDesc.support: Contains what appears to be the earliest use of European paper in for a manuscript produced in Iran, comprised of cross-grained, ivoury-coloured laid handmade paper, ~1 mm between laid lines, with distinct vertical chain lines approximately ~32–37 mm apart. Watermarked with a balance within a circle (including conjugate folios 112–113) and a darker paper watermarked with a tulip (including conjugate folios 76–77), that indicate likely manufacture in Italy. Note one folio of this same stock precedes folio 1.
supportDesc.foliation: Foliated in pencilled Arabic numberal on the upper left corners of the a sides, but off by 1, as noted on the first and last folios and accounted for in this record.
supportDesc.collation: Primarily triternions throughout. 1I+1(2)45III-1(270); both the final conjugate folio and another leaf between folios 35–36 appear missing. Catchwords throughout on the lower-left corners of the b sides.
supportDesc.condition: Moderate insect damage throughout the textblock. Extensive repairs to the gutters from folios247–70 with 253 detached. Joint cracking by the head on the left board with frayed headcaps.

layoutDesc.layout: 2 columns throughout, with 14 lines per page. Ruled with a miṣṭārah hand guide.

handDesc.handNote: Copied in a miniscule nasta‘liq hand in black by Mun‘im al-Dīn al-Awḥadī, with repeating headers written in laternating ultramarine and gold inks.

list.item: First right flyeleaf b side (f. ib): D.F. 233 and priced £5.15.6, consistent with Duncan Forbes (1798–1868) catalogue, p. 76..
Third right flyeleaf a side (f. iiia): bears the title inscribed in Persian in black ink with the transliterated Latin script with the number 49 in pencil and the latter again in sepia.
Fourth right flyeleaf a side (f. iva): bears the title inscribed in Devanagari script in black ink with the tralsiterated Latin script with the number 49 in pencil and the latter again in sepia.

Notes: Folio 1a bears several notations, with the number 79 at top, followed by the title, Risālah dar Ṣaydīyah, then incorrectly states that it has 72 folios, followed by prices in Indian raqam script.
Bookplates: left paste-down, Bibliotheca Lindesiana with shelf mark F/10, and former class mark No. 61 crossed out.

binding.p: Abbreviated resewing with European-style decorative front-bead endbands over a flat cord core in solely dark blue indigo-dyed silk threads. Rebound, probably in Britain, in the early-mid 19th century in full, finely-diced Russian goatskin leather, withe a hollow-backed spine that bears five false bands, but left untitled. British-made combed marbled made endpapers

decoNote.p: Boards blind-tooled in the European manner with an Islamic-inspired central mandorla comprised of four impressions with two matching corner tools and bold scrollwork flourish serving as pendants, attached to the centres with blind lines, and bounded by an insular dot roll surrounded by thick-and-lines on the perimetres of the boards, with the board edges decorated with a narrow decorative roll feating a zig-zag with interspersed trefoils, while the interior dentelles bear a wider roll with a dotted zig-zag and interspersed triangular palmette motifs. Spine blind paletted with thick-and-thin fillet lines on either side of the false raised bands.

binding.condition: Binding in good condition. Slight cracking at headcaps.

history.provenance: Formerly owned by unidentified individuals named Muḥammad Taqī, al-Faqīr Muḥammad bin Pīr Muḥammad, and Muḥammad Sarvīn(?) Muḥammad Qulī

provenance.p: Subsequently acquired by orientalist Duncan Forbes (1798–1868), who sold his collection of manuscripts to his publisher W. H. Allen & Co. in exchange for an annuity. Subsequently sold by that firm to Alexander Lindsay, 25th Earl of Crawford (1812–1880) in 1866
Purchased by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1901 from James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford (1847–1913).

acquisition.p: Bequeathed by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1908 to the John Rylands Library.

source.p: Bibliographical description based on an index created by Reza Navabpour circa 1993, derived from a manuscript handlist by Michael Kerney, circa 1890s and his Bibliotheca Lindesiana, Hand-list of Oriental Manuscripts: Arabic, Persian, Turkish, 1898.
Manuscript description by Jake Benson in 2021 with reference to the volume.

availability.p: The manuscript is available for consultation by any accredited reader, see Becoming a Reader for details. Please contact uml.special-collections@manchester.ac.uk for further information on the availability of this manuscript.
